writing_prompt: A writer, desperate to please his mother, attempts to craft a children's story, only to find her critique sharper than any editor's and her demand for a happy ending far more challenging than he anticipated.
story:
The writer's cluttered desk was a sea of crumpled drafts and ink-stained fingers, a testament to the countless hours he'd spent trying to please his mother. His childhood stories had always been met with praise and admiration, but as he grew older, the stakes seemed to rise. His mother, a retired teacher, had always been his toughest critic, and he knew that if he could just write a story that made her proud, he'd be able to silence the doubts that had been plaguing him since he started writing seriously.

The story, a children's tale about a brave little rabbit who outsmarts a sly fox, had been his mother's idea. She'd read it to him when he was a child, and he'd always remembered the way the words made him feel – safe, happy, and full of wonder. But as he sat at his desk, staring at the blank page in front of him, he couldn't shake the feeling that something was off.

His mother had been clear in her instructions: the story had to have a happy ending, and it had to be suitable for children of all ages. Easy enough, right? But as he began to write, he found himself struggling to come up with a plot that fit her vision. The rabbit and the fox were great characters, but how were they supposed to resolve their differences in a way that was both satisfying and kid-friendly?

He spent the next few hours typing away, trying to force the story into shape. But no matter what he wrote, his mother's voice kept echoing in his head, critiquing every sentence, every paragraph, and every character decision. "This isn't happy enough," she'd say. "The rabbit needs to be more brave." Or, "The fox needs to be more menacing."

He rubbed his temples, feeling the familiar ache of frustration. Why was this so hard? He'd written countless stories before, but never had he faced such fierce scrutiny from someone he loved. His friends and fellow writers were always supportive, but his mother was different. She was his biggest fan, and also his toughest critic.

Just then, his mother walked into the room, a cup of coffee in one hand and a stack of papers in the other. "How's it going?" she asked, her eyes scanning the page on his computer screen.

He hesitated, unsure of how to answer. "It's...complicated," he said finally.

She set the coffee down and sat beside him, her eyes scanning the page again. "Let me take a look," she said, her voice softening.

As she read, her face grew more and more serious. "This isn't it," she said, her voice firm but not unkind. "The rabbit is too cowardly, and the fox is too...I don't know, too cute, I guess."

He felt a surge of defensiveness, but he tried to push it down. This was his mother, after all. He wanted to make her proud. "What do you think I should do instead?" he asked, trying to sound calm.

She leaned back in her chair, steepling her fingers together. "I think you should make the rabbit more proactive," she said. "Give him a real challenge to overcome. And the fox should be more...formidable, I suppose."

He nodded, taking a deep breath. He could do this. He could write a story that would make his mother proud.

But as he began to write again, he found himself struggling to make the changes she'd suggested. The rabbit was too perfect, too easy to like. And the fox was too cartoonish, too one-dimensional. He tried to add more nuance to both characters, but it felt forced, artificial.

As the hours ticked by, his frustration grew. He was stuck, unable to move forward with the story. His mother, sensing his distress, got up and made him another cup of coffee. "You're doing your best," she said, her voice soft. "That's all anyone can ask for."

But he knew that wasn't true. His mother wanted more. She wanted a story that was perfect, a story that would make her proud. And he was starting to realize that he might not be able to deliver that.

As he sat there, staring at the page in front of him, he felt a sense of despair wash over him. He was a writer, but he was also his mother's son. And sometimes, that felt like a heavier burden than he could bear.

His mother sat down beside him again, her eyes scanning the page. "What's wrong?" she asked, her voice gentle.

He shook his head, feeling a lump form in his throat. "I don't know," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. "I just can't seem to get it right."

She put a hand on his shoulder, her touch warm and comforting. "It's okay," she said. "It's just a story. It's not the end of the world."

But as he looked at her, he felt a surge of frustration. It wasn't just a story. It was his story, the one he'd been trying to write for weeks. And it was his mother's expectations that were holding him back.

He took a deep breath, trying to calm down. He knew that he couldn't please everyone, not even his own mother. But he also knew that he couldn't give up. Not yet.

"I'll keep trying," he said finally, his voice firm.

His mother smiled, her eyes shining with pride. "I know you will," she said. "And I'll be here to help you every step of the way."

As he watched her get up and leave the room, he felt a sense of determination wash over him. He would write this story, no matter what it took. And he would make his mother proud, even if it killed him.

But as he sat there, staring at the page in front of him, he couldn't shake the feeling that he was trapped in a never-ending cycle of disappointment and frustration. And that the story he was trying to write was just a symptom of a deeper problem – one that he wasn't sure he was ready to face.
